relationships.notes: Married partner whose shared household, travel, and teaching ministry frame Aquila’s vocational identity across Corinth, Ephesus, and later greetings.
Hosts Paul, labors with him at the shared tentmaking trade, and is celebrated for risking his life to safeguard Paul’s Gentile mission.
Together with Priscilla, instructs Apollos more accurately in the way of God, helping refine another prominent teacher.

traits.origin_and_trade: Introduced as a Jew from Pontus who, with his wife Priscilla, had recently come from Italy because Claudius had ordered all Jews to leave Rome; works as a tentmaker.
traits.partnership_with_paul: Hosts Paul in Corinth, working together at the same trade and sharing life and mission.
traits.mobility_in_mission: Accompanies Paul as he leaves Corinth, traveling with him to Ephesus before remaining there for further ministry.
traits.instruction_of_apollos: Together with Priscilla, takes Apollos aside in Ephesus and explains the way of God more accurately, shaping another influential teacher.

traits.coworker_and_risk_taker: Named with Prisca/Priscilla as Paul’s coworkers who risked their necks for his life, prompting thanks from Paul and all the churches of the Gentiles.
traits.house_church_leaders: Host a church in their house, indicating a role in leading and organizing local assemblies.
traits.network_and_greetings: Appear in Paul’s greetings as trusted collaborators whose presence strengthens communities in different cities.

traits.later_tradition: Greeted, along with Prisca, in a later letter, suggesting continued prominence within the network of Pauline churches.
traits.critical_note: This greeting occurs in a letter widely regarded by critical scholarship as post-Pauline, reflecting the enduring memory of the couple’s ministry.
